awd_titl_txt: CREST Center for Energy and Sustainability at California State University, Los Angeles
awd_abstract_narration:
Center for Energy and Sustainability

With National Science Foundation support, the California State University, Los Angeles Center for Energy and Sustainability will engage in research on energy and energy-related materials and technologies. The overarching purpose of the Center is the development and production of novel materials with renewable energy applications. Center researchers plan to develop a novel fuel cell and assess its efficiency; address several key issues that have precluded development of more efficient solar cells to harvest solar power for electricity generation; and help reduce energy loss in power transmission. Center activities include the establishment of core materials and characterization facilities as well as a Master's degree program in Materials Science and Engineering. The Center will increase the number of student participants; as well as  the number of CREST trained underrepresented minority students accepted into doctoral programs.

The Center's research agenda addresses both fundamental and applied problems in energy science and technology. The "Microfluidic-based Fuel Cells and Optimization" subproject will develop chip-based fuel cells and efficient catalysts for powering portable devices. Research focuses on developing and accessing paper microfluidic fuel cells. Paper-based devices have attracted widespread attention due to their low cost, portability, and minimal sample and reagent volume requirement. Research also focuses on the development of formic acid, methanol, and hydrogen fuel cells on polydimethysiloxane platforms using Nafion membranes.  In the subproject on "Advanced Materials for Photovoltaic Cells," new inorganic and organic nanomaterials are integrated into photovoltaic cells so that electricity can be generated in an efficient and environmentally friendly manner. Research focuses on ruthenium dye-sensitized cells, as well as on perovskite cells. The subproject, "Properties and Applications of Overdoped High-Temperature Superconductors," correlates the structures to functions of both low- and high-temperature superconductors. The goal is to discover superconductivity at temperatures high enough to revolutionize energy related technologies. This subproject also involves applied research on high-temperature superconducting tapes to enhance their critical densities and irreversibility fields for high-current applications such as power cables and high-field magnets. Synergy among the three subprojects stems from their thematic overlap and complementarity.

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: CENTERS FOR RSCH EXCELL IN S&T

por.por_cntn:
Overview: On April 1, 2016, Cal State LA was awarded a CREST Phase II grant (NSF-HRD-1547723), to support three innovative research subprojects and a student education and training program in the Center for Energy and Sustainability (CEaS). Its main objectives were: (a) to continue and expand the institutional efforts in recruitment, retention, and graduation of underrepresented minority students (URMs) in the STEM fields. (b) To transform the Center into a nationally recognized research entity with emphases on energy and energy-related materials and technologies. (c) To conduct innovative and multidisciplinary research among the Center faculty and through collaborations with industry and partnering institutions.


Outcomes: For the past six and a half years (including a no-cost extension of one and a half years), the research, education and outreach activities of the CREST CEaS have led to achievements that met seven goals ? associated with the three aforementioned objectives ? with the following outcomes. (1) Faculty from the Colleges of Engineering, Computer Science, and Technology (ECST), and Natural and Social Sciences (NSS), have achieved a publication rate of 52 products per year, representing an increase by a factor of 1.8 over the already impressive level of the previous Phase I grant. (2) The Center faculty have garnered 45 additional grants totaling 17 million dollars. (3) About 8% of the CREST CEaS funding was directed to establish a regional core facility for materials characterization and surface analysis. The Materials Characterization laboratory has started to take shape, and the CREST CEaS grant has been key in expanding the research infrastructure of Cal State LA. (4) A new MS degree program in Material Science and Engineering (MSE), has been created, fully implemented and institutionalized. Currently the MS in MSE is in its third year of operation and has 20 students in the most recent cohort. (5) The number of CREST CEaS faculty supported by the program increased by a factor of 3, with special emphasis being placed on recruiting 17 young-career faculty members, 3 mid-range faculty members, and 1 new full professor. The support and mentoring activities from CREST CEaS have contributed to the success of these recruited faculty members by helping establish their research lines and advancing their faculty careers. (6) The CREST CEaS recruitment, retention, and graduation activities increased by a factor of 2.1, with 188 students directly involved in research activities. In addition, the center outreach activities, including workshops and the seminar series, have benefitted 412 middle school, high school and community college students interested in STEM fields. Finally, (7) out of the 188 students directly supported/involved in research activities, 36% have continued into MS and/or PhD programs in STEM, with another 64% being in the workforce of industry.


Research Projects: Three synergistic subprojects, a modeling component, an education and outreach component, and three partnership supplement projects, all under the unified of Energy and Sustainability, were successfully implemented and performed using experimental and numerical approaches. For example, the Microfluidic-based Fuel Cells and Optimization subproject designed, analyzed, and developed small-scale fuel cells, batteries, and efficient catalysts for powering portable devices. In the subproject on Advanced Materials for Photovoltaic Cells, new inorganic and organic nanomaterials have been integrated into photovoltaic cells to increase the efficiency in the conversion of solar energy into electricity, in an environmentally friendly manner. The subproject on Properties and Applications of Overdoped High-Temperature Superconductors, successfully focused on basic and applied physics research to correlate the structures to functions of both low- and high-temperature superconductors, and on the interplay between ferromagnetism and unconventional superconductivity of a variety of novel materials. On the other hand, the Modeling Component provided essential support on mathematical modeling and numerical analyses to the three subprojects. In addition, it successfully developed, implemented and applied a variety of numerical and soft computing (artificial intelligence) techniques to design, control and optimize thermal and energy systems at both the macro- and micro-scale levels. All projects have been spearheaded by highly productive researchers with a strong track record of working with undergraduate and MS students. Finally, the Educational and Outreach Component has successfully implemented a comprehensive recruitment, training and mentoring program directed toward increasing the participation of undergraduate and graduate URM students in energy, sustainable energy- and water-related systems, materials science, and engineering.


Conclusion: The research, educational and outreach activities of the CREST CEaS program, along with their corresponding outcomes, have made possible not only to consolidate it as a nationally recognized center focused on energy and energy-related materials and technologies, but also to establish the evolution of its research agenda into an expanded research umbrella focused on urban sustainability. This new NSF-funded center, CREST Center for Advancement toward Sustainable Urban Systems (CATSUS), is in its first year of activity.


Last Modified: 12/27/2022
Modified by: Arturo Pacheco-Vega
